text:
FINAL REPORT
 AP CHEST 03:03 A.M. ON [**2129-12-27**]

 HISTORY:  Urosepsis.  Emphysema.  Atrial fibrillation.

FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL INDICATION:  Preoperative assessment.

 The mediastinal and hilar contours are within normal limits.  There is
 increased opacity within the right lower lobe and also in a portion of the
 right middle lobe with associated volume loss, manifested by inferior and
 medial displacement of the major fissure.  There is some fluid extending into
 the major fissure.  The left lung is clear except for minimal discoid
 atelectasis at the left lung base and a possible small left pleural effusion.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: 64 year old male with status post recent STE MI. Now with
 increasing edema and shortness of breath.

 AP supine single view of the chest is compared to [**2101-3-24**].

 FINDINGS: The heart is enlarged in size but stable in the interval.
 Mediastinal contour is unchanged. There is upper zone redistribution of the
 pulmonary artery vasculature. Perihilar haziness as well as diffuse bilateral
 pulmonary opacities. These findings are consistent with acute CHF. There are
 also bilateral pleural effusions. There is barium in the left colon from
 previous contrast study.

IMPRESSION:

 1.  Interval decrease in adenopathy within the chest abdomen and pelvis.

 2.  Decreased splenomegaly, now 15 cm.

 3.  Progressive compression of the T11 and L2 vertebral bodies, likely
 osteoporotic.

IMPRESSION:
 1.  No acute intra-abdominal process.
 2.  Fatty liver.
 3.  Status post presumed appendectomy.

IMPRESSION:

 1) No pneumothorax.
 2) New small bilateral pleural effusions and mild bibasilar atelectasis.
IMPRESSION:  No obstruction or perforation.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Status post chest tube removal.  Evaluate for pneumothorax.

 TECHNIQUE:  PA and lateral views of the chest were obtained, compared with
 examination performed 2 days ago.

 FINDINGS:  There has been interval removal of both the right-sided IJ central
 venous catheter as well as the left-sided basilar chest tube.  NG tube has
 also been removed as has been the mediastinal drain.  No evidence of
 pneumothorax.  There is bibasilar atelectasis, right worse than left, with
 associated left retrocardiac opacity, probably relating to atelectasis.  No
 significant pleural effusions are evident.  Note is made of a curvilinear
 radiopacity projecting over the left upper abdomen, probably within the
 stomach, and likely represents radiopaque medication or enteric contrast
 material within the stomach.  Sternotomy sutures appear intact.  Mediastinal
 clips are again seen.

FINAL REPORT
 CHEST SINGLE AP FILM:

 HISTORY: ICD placement and shortness of breath.

 There is a right sided dual chamber ICD with leads unchanged in location in
 this single view compared with the prior film of [**2101-5-25**]. No pneumothorax.
 There is cardiomegaly with upper zone redistribution, bilateral pleural
 effusions and associated bibasilar atelectases. Consolidation at the lung
 bases cannot be ruled out.

INDICATION:  30-year-old female pregnant with TTP-HUS and severe preeclampsia
 with low platelet count.  Requiring urgent plasmapheresis.

 OPERATORS:  Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 730**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 501**] (fellow) and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 731**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 63**] (attending).

 ANESTHESIA:  Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of
 fentanyl (25 cmcg) over the total intra-service time of 20 minutes during
 which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored.

 PROCEDURE:  After risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the
 patient, written informed consent was obtained.  The patient was brought to
 the angiography suite and placed supine on the table.  The right neck was
 prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure timeout and
 huddle were performed per standard [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.  The patient was placed in
 left semi-lateral decubitus position (LPO-[**Doctor Last Name 14451**]).

 Under son[**Name (NI) 536**] guidance with hard copy images on file, the right internal
 jugular vein was cannulated with a 21-gauge micropuncture needle through which
 a 0.018 wire was advanced into the superior vena cava.  The needle was
 exchanged for a micropuncture sheath.  The inner dilator and wire were removed
 and a short [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  Over the
 wire, sequential dilation was performed up to 14 French and the triple-lumen
 hemodialysis catheter (including VIP port) was advanced over the wire with tip
 terminating in the right atrium.  The wire was removed and the catheter
 aspirated and flushed easily.  A final fluoroscopic image of the chest was
 obtained from this location.  The catheter was sutured to the skin with 0 silk
 suture and capped and dressed appropriately.  There were no immediate
 complications.

IMPRESSION:  Findings consistent with pulmonary edema and bilateral pleural
 effusions.  Findings may represent some interval worsening, also be due, at
 least in part, to change in patient positioning.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  80-year-old female with pleural effusion.

 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph [**2184-9-29**].

 TWO VIEWS OF THE CHEST:  The large right perihilar opacity/effusion have
 nearly resolved, with only small residual right pleural fluid.  The right
 basilar pleural catheter is in unchanged position.  The aorta is tortuous and
 heavily calcified.  The bony thorax is markedly distorted by severe S-shaped
 scoliosis, and kyphosis, and degenerative change of the thoracic spine.

FINAL REPORT
 ____ insertion.

 Chest fluoroscopy without Radiologist. Single spot film from the OR
 demonstrates a catheter within the field of view the tip of which is not
 included in the spot film.

PROVISIONAL FINDINGS IMPRESSION (PFI): JMGw FRI [**2102-10-27**] 6:47 AM
  PFI:

  1.  Stable size of a right intraparenchymal hemorrhage with intraventricular
  extension.  No new hemorrhage.

  2.  Slight increased surrounding vasogenic edema as the adjacent sulci and
  gyri appear somewhat more effaced.

  3.  Stable mass effect upon the right lateral ventricle, although there is no
  shift of midline, stable.

  Findings were discussed via telephone with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 3011**] [**Name (STitle) 3012**] at 5:25 a.m. on
  [**2102-10-27**].
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 IMPRESSION:

 1.  Stable size of a right intraparenchymal hemorrhage with intraventricular
 extension.  No new hemorrhage.

 2.  Slight increased surrounding vasogenic edema as the adjacent sulci and
 gyri appear somewhat more effaced.
 3.  Stable mass effect upon the right lateral ventricle, although there is no
 shift of midline, stable.

 Findings were discussed via telephone with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 3011**] [**Name (STitle) 3012**] at 5:25 a.m. on
 [**2102-10-27**].

FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  30-year-old female, 24 weeks pregnant with TTP, requiring
 placement of temporary triple-lumen pheresis line with VIP port.

 OPERATORS:  Procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 234**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 896**] (fellow).  Dr.
 [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the attending radiologist, supervised and  reviewed the study.

 ANESTHESIA:  1% local lidocaine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  After the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the
 procedure were explained to the patient, informed consent was obtained. The
 potential risks of radiation in a pregnant patient were also reviewed and
 confirmed with the patient.  She was brought to the angiography suite and
 placed supine on the imaging table.  Her abdomen was shielded and the neck and
 indwelling right pheresis catheter were prepped and draped in the usual
 sterile fashion.  A pre-procedural timeout and huddle were performed per [**Hospital1 184**]
 protocol.  Under ultrasound guidance with hard copy images on file, a
 micropuncture set was used to access the left internal jugular vein and a
 0.018 wire was advanced into the SVC. This was subsequently exchanged for a
 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire. A 12 French x 16 cm pheresis catheter with VIP was selected
 and after sequential fascial dilatation, the catheter was placed over the wire
 with the tip positioned in the distal SVC.  The catheter was secured to the
 skin with 0 silk suture.  The catheter was flushed and aspirated well.  A
 final fluoroscopic spot image demonstrated good position of the catheter and
 no pneumothorax.

 The patient was then placed on a gurney and the indwelling right pheresis
 catheter was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complication.

FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  Left leg edema.  Evaluate for deep vein thrombus.

 VASCULAR ULTRASOUND LEFT LEG.

 COMPARISON SCAN:  [**2124-11-23**].

 Normal flow and compressibility was present in the left common femoral,
 superficial femoral, and popliteal veins.  Normal variation with breathing was
 seen indicating absence of thrombus inthe more proximal [**Last Name (un) 49508**]. The visualized
 portion of iliac vein appeared normal.

 The right side was evaluated for comparison.  This too shows no evidence of
 thrombus.

FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old woman presenting with microscopic hematuria
 and acute renal failure.  Evaluate for obstruction.

 FINDINGS:  The right kidney measures 10.1 cm in length.  The left kidney
 measures 11.5 cm in length.  There is no evidence of hydronephrosis or focal
 renal masses.  No perinephric fluid is noted.  No kidney stones are
 appreciated.  Within the lower pole of the left kidney is a 1.1-cm cyst with
 echogenic material, likely representing milk of calcium.  The bladder is
 moderately distended without clear abnormalities.  No free fluid is noted in
 the abdomen.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  [**Last Name (Titles) 74643**] placement.

 FINDINGS:  In comparison with the study of [**3-15**], the tip of the [**Date Range 74643**], now lies
 approximately 3.6 cm below the transverse arch of the aorta.  Otherwise,
 little change with extensive opacification at the left base consistent with
 moderate pleural effusion and underlying atelectasis.

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE HEAD ULTRASOUND, [**2178-3-19**]

 CLINICAL DATA: Infant with two vessel cord born at 33 week gestation.

 FINDINGS:
 There is no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage, mass, extraaxial collection
 or ventricular dilatation.  The corpus callosum is present but appears
 somewhat thinned.  No other abnormalities seen.

WET READ: IPf [**Doctor First Name 137**] [**2124-11-30**] 7:53 PM
  No large pneumothorax.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 AP CHEST 7:26 P.M. [**11-30**]

 HISTORY:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old woman with a right pleural effusion after thoracentesis.

IMPRESSION:
 1.  Frontal bone fracture which involves the inner and outer tables of the
 frontal sinus.
 2.  Tiny foci of hyperattenuation near the interhemispheric fissure, likely
 representing small subdural hematomas.

 Findings were communicated to the EU via CCC.

FINAL REPORT

 INDICATION:  Missing instrumentation.

 SINGLE AP PORTABLE ABDOMEN:  The study was performed in the operating room.
 There is a midline vertical staple line, and nasogastric tube in the stomach,
 one JP drainage tube curling in the left flank from the left side, another
 drainage tube curling along the right side of the abdomen terminating in the
 midline at L5, another drain from the left superior region terminating in the
 mid abdomen, and multiple clips centered in the right side of the abdomen and
 pelvis. A single linear radiodensity between the lateral aspects of the right
 tenth and eleventh ribs was seen on the CT scan of [**2193-9-27**]. Bowel gas
 pattern has no evidence of obstruction.

WET READ: [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 1604**] [**Doctor First Name 137**] [**2170-5-17**] 8:16 PM
  R PICC ends in the Right atrium. if pulled back 4cm, it will be in lower SVC.
  -MAgarwal d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] (IV RN) by phone at 8:15pm [**2170-5-17**].
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  66-year-old woman with CLL and new PICC.  Additional views
 obtained for placement of PICC.

 COMPARISON:  Portable chest radiograph from [**2170-5-17**].

 FINDINGS:  Oblique and lateral views of the chest were obtained.  There is a
 right PICC line with the tip in the right atrium.  There is otherwise no
 significant change from the prior radiograph.  There is no new parenchymal
 infiltrate, pneumothorax or pleural effusions. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is
 stable.
IMPRESSION:  Right lower lobe infiltrate persists.

INDICATION:  Right basal ganglia hemorrhage, evaluate change.

 COMPARISON:  [**2102-10-27**].

 NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT:

 An intraparenchymal hematoma within the right basal ganglia is stable in size,
 currently measuring 38 x 26 mm, previously 39 x 27 mm.  Intraventricular
 extension is again noted into the adjacent lateral ventricle, with some
 redistribution of this intraventricular component now seen layering within the
 occipital horns.  There is no extension into the third or fourth ventricles.
 There is no new focus of intracranial hemorrhage identified.  The extent of
 vasogenic edema and associated mass effect is grossly stable from one day
 prior.  There is focal mass effect upon the right lateral ventricle, without
 significant shift of midline structures.  The ventricles are stable in size,
 without development of hydrocephalus.  The basal cisterns remain patent.
 Accounting for underlying chronic small vessel ischemic changes in the
 periventricular white matter, the [**Doctor Last Name 34**]-white matter differentiation is
 preserved.  There is no evidence of acute vascular territory infarction.

 The osseous structures demonstrate no suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous
 lesions.  Visualized paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells are again clear.

IMPRESSION: 1.  No definite change in bilateral perihilar infiltrates.
 2.  Small-to-moderate sized bilateral pleural effusions.

CONCLUSION:  Bilateral nodules.  The nodule in the mid-to-lower pole of the
 right lobe of the thyroid should be considered for fine needle aspiration.
 Results were placed in the critical report dashboard.

IMPRESSION:

 1.  Status post right hemicolectomy, with unremarkable appearance of the
 ileocolonic anastomosis, without evidence of local recurrence.

 2.  Interval resolution of a few pulmonary nodules.  Few remaining sub-5-mm
 pulmonary nodules in both lungs are non-specific and are either unchanged or
 slightly smaller since the prior study.  Recommended followup chest CT in six
 months to assess interval change.

 3.  A stable 8-mm focus of enhancement within segment VII of the liver likely
 represents a flash-filling hemangioma or an FNH.

 4.  No evidence of new metastatic disease in the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

 Findings added to radiology critical findings dashboard.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Followup of mediastinal hematoma.

 COMPARISON:  [**2185-1-4**].

 In comparison to previous examination, the extent of the right-sided pleural
 effusion has markedly decreased.  The extent of the left-sided pleural
 effusion is almost unchanged.  The situation of the lung parenchyma is also
 unchanged.  No other relevant changes.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  74-year-old male with history of trauma.  Patient with known prior
 ICH.  Currently, patient with worsening mental status. Evaluation for interval
 change.

 COMPARISON:  Non-contrast head CT from [**2200-11-20**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images were obtained through the brain.  No
 contrast was administered.

 NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT:

 Compared to the prior, there is new intraventricular hemorrhage seen in the
 occipital [**Doctor Last Name 218**] of the left lateral ventricle.  Additionally, the frontal [**Doctor Last Name 218**]
 of the left lateral ventricle measures 1.9 cm, which is slightly larger than
 prior (1.6 cm).

 Again seen is diffuse bifrontal subarachnoid hemorrhage which appears
 unchanged.  The intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe, left
 frontal lobe, right mid brain and pons, right thalamus, and left
 pontocerebellar angle appears grossly unchanged compared to prior.  The focus
 of subarachnoid hemorrhage seen in the right posterior frontal lobe appears
 unchanged. The right parafalcine subdural hematoma appears stable.

 Opacification of the maxillary sinuses, sphenoid sinuses and nasopharynx is
 improved compared to prior.  The mastoid air cells continue to be well
 aerated.  The left frontal bone and left temporal bone fractures are
 unchanged.

IMPRESSION:

 Post-reconstruction of right frontal bone with near anatomic alignment. Post-
 surgical pneumocephalus and subcutaneous emphysema.  Left small frontal
 subdural hematoma is slightly larger compared to prior study.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  84-year-old male with mediastinal hematoma seen on outside hospital
 study.  Hypotension.

 No prior images available at this hospital.

 AP PORTABLE CHEST:  The mediastinal contours are markedly abnormal with
 bulging convexity of the aorticopulmonary window and widening of the aortic
 knob.  There is soft tissue density circumferentially surrounding the aortic
 arch, consistent with known aortic leak and mediastinal hematoma.  The trachea
 is deviated to the right by the enlarged aortic arch. There is no evidence of
 apical pleural capping. The lung parenchyma appears grossly clear, and there
 is no overt congestive failure. There is a left sided pleural effusion. There
 is focal pleural thickening laterally on the right. The bones are
 demineralized.

PROVISIONAL FINDINGS IMPRESSION (PFI): SHSf MON [**2122-11-30**] 3:34 PM
  No acute cardiopulmonary process with tiny bilateral pleural effusions.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process with tiny bilateral pleural
 effusions.

IMPRESSION:  Improved aeration at the right lung base with minimal residual
 plate-like atelectasis in the lower lungs.  No pneumothorax.
                                                                       SESHa

IMPRESSION:  Cardiomegaly without evidence of failure; new retrocardiac
 collapse/consolidation and bilateral effusions.

IMPRESSION:
 1.  Right upper zone opacity, possibly cavitary, possibly related to a
 laceration, but infection, including active tuberculosis, cannot be ruled out.
 Please correlate with symptoms and history.
 2.  Very large gastric air bubble.  An orogastric tube appears appropriately
 positioned.
 3.  ET tube terminating 7.5 cm above the carina.

IMPRESSION: Right subclavian line with tip in distal SVC. No pneumothorax. No
 acute cardiopulmonary process.

FINAL REPORT
 CT OF THE NECK WITH CONTRAST.

 INDICATION:  Hemiparesis and odontoid fracture.

 Helical images were obtained through the neck after dynamic intravenous
 contrast administration.  Correlation is made to the MRI examination of the
 spine from [**2109-1-5**].  There is evidence for spinal canal stenosis and
 posterocentral spurring with mild compression of the ventral aspect of the
 cord at C5-6 and C6-7 levels.  There is a type II fracture involving the dens
 with minimal rotational subluxation of C1 in relation to C2.  There is no
 compromise of the canal at the cervicomedullary junction.  No displacement of
 the odontoid process is seen on this examination.  No definite fractures could
 be identified involving the base of the skull.

 There are no soft-tissue mass lesions associated around the odontoid process.
 A few scattered nonspecific lymph nodes are seen within the posterior triangle
 of the neck bilaterally which measure less than 4 mm and are nonspecific in
 nature.  There is no adenopathy in the nasopharynx.  Limited images obtained
 through the upper chest were unremarkable.  A small infarct is again noted
 involving the left paracentral aspect of the pons which was presumably
 subacute in nature.

FINAL REPORT
 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION:  IV access needed for IV fluids.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 64**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 65**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 65**],
 the Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a double lumen PICC line measuring 39 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guide wire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE HEAD ULTRASOUND

 HISTORY:  Preterm infant, now term equivalent post-menstrual age.

 Comparison is [**1-4**].

 Ventricles are normal in size and configuration.  There is no evidence for
 intraventricular, intraparenchymal, or extra-axial hemorrhage.  Extra-axial
 fluid spaces are normal.  Posterior fossa and midline structures are normal.

FINAL REPORT
 PA AND LATERAL CHEST ON [**6-29**]

 HISTORY:  Abnormal outside chest radiograph:

 Prior chest radiographs are not provided for review.

 Horizontally oriented opacities in the right upper chest correspond to the
 costosternal junctions, although there could be lung lesions fortuitously
 distributed.  Nevertheless, the lateral view shows a nearly 2-cm wide round
 radiopacity projecting over the retrosternal lung which could be another or
 one of the same lung lesions, particularly the portion projecting over the
 right first anterior interspace.  Any other chest radiograph should be
 obtained for side-by-side comparison, supplemented by either oblique views or
 chest CT scanning.  There is no evidence of central adenopathy.  The heart is
 normal size and there is no pleural effusion.

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE CHEST ON [**5-25**].

 INDICATION:  Shortness of breath, status post upgraded ICD.

 FINDINGS:  Compared with [**2101-5-21**], moderate-sized bilateral, right greater than
 left pleural effusions persist.  There is persistent volume loss involving
 both lower lobes.  The perihilar infiltrates/pulmonary edema are probably not
 significantly changed, allowing for some motion artifacts on the right
 hemithorax.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  66-year-old woman with CLL, recent viral pneumonia with new
 pulmonary nodule.

 COMPARISONS:  CT chest without contrast from [**2170-7-17**], CT torso with
 contrast from [**2170-6-28**].

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axial imaging was obtained through the chest without the
 administration of intravenous contrast material and 5 and 1.25 mm axial slices
 coronal and sagittal reformats were completed.

 FINDINGS:  Thyroid gland is unremarkable.  There are no pathologically
 enlarged supraclavicular, axillary or mediastinal lymph nodes.  Small sub-5-mm
 mediastinal lymph nodes are present and similar in size and distribution to
 the prior study.  There are mild coronary artery calcifications.  Small
 pericardial effusion has slightly increased since the prior study which in an
 immunocompromised setting could be suggestive of pericarditis.  The airways
 are patent to the subsegmental levels.

 LUNGS:  Since the recent prior study, there has been significant improvement
 in multiple ground-glass opacities predominantly in the right upper lobe with
 only minimal ground-glass opacities persisting.  The nodule seen in the right
 lower lobe on the prior study measuring 6 mm is no longer identified on this
 exam.  However, there are multiple new nodules with surrounding halos since
 the prior study.  For example, 5-mm right lower lobe nodule (4:174), 3-mm left
 lower lobe nodule (4:144), 2 mm left lower lobe nodule (4:134), 4 mm lingular
 nodule (4:116) are new. In immunocompromise host, the new nodules with
 surrounding halos are concerning for fungal infection.  However, if patient is
 not immunocompromised, differential includes viral infection, new bacterial
 infection, COP or less likely vasculitis.  There is no definite focal
 consolidation or pleural effusion.

 This study is not tailored for evaluation of the subdiaphragmatic structures
 but shows multiple calcifications in the spleen, unchanged from prior exam.

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  Since the recent prior study from [**2170-7-17**] prior
 study, there is new slight wedging of the superior endplate of L2.  Since the
 CT torso from [**2170-6-28**], there is also new deformity of the superior
 endplate of T11.  There are no other concerning lytic or sclerotic lesions.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  83-year-old female with history of lung cancer status post right
 upper lobe resection, now with new lower extremity edema.

 COMPARISON:  [**2116-3-25**] and [**2112-2-16**].

 CHEST, PA AND LATERAL:  Surgical suture chains are seen within the right mid-
 to-upper lung.  Aside from minimal left basilar subsegmental atelectasis, the
 lungs are clear.  No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is identified.  The
 heart is normal in size, with a mildly unfolded aorta.  Prominence of the
 right hilum is unchanged across multiple prior studies dating back to [**2-16**], [**2112**].  Cholecystectomy clips overlie the right upper quadrant of the
 abdomen.  A VP shunt is partially imaged, and courses along the right chest.

FINAL REPORT
 PA AND LATERAL VIEWS OF THE CHEST

 REASON FOR EXAM:  Preop evaluation, left inguinal hernia repair.

 Cardiomediastinal contours are normal.  The lungs are clear.  There is no
 pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  Mild degenerative changes are in the
 thoracic spine.  There is mild right lower thoracic scoliosis.

IMPRESSION:

 No radiopaque foreign bodies near the orbits.  Please note that the patient
 does have hearing aids bilaterally, which should be removed prior to MR
 scanning.

FINAL REPORT
 CHEST RADIOGRAPH.

 COMPARISON:  CT spine from OSH from today.

 CLINICAL HISTORY:  57-year-old man with intracranial hemorrhage, C2 fracture,
 question acute process in the chest.

 FINDINGS:  Two AP images of the chest were obtained portably with patient
 supine.  Comparison with a CT C-spine from same date from an outside hospital.
 The lungs appear essentially clear bilaterally without focal consolidation,
 effusion, or signs of CHF.  A skinfold projecting over the lateral margin of
 the left lung simulates a pneumothorax though no definite sign of pneumothorax
 is seen and there is no pneumothorax seen in the imaged lung apices on the CT
 C-spine from earlier today.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette appears
 unremarkable, though aorta is somewhat unfolded.  The imaged osseous
 structures appear intact.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Screening.  No complaints today.

 SCREENING MAMMOGRAM:  Comparison is made with a prior [**Hospital1 51**] mammogram dated
 [**2174-12-21**].  The breast tissues are predominantly fatty.  There is no
 evidence of dominant or spiculated mass, suspicious clustered
 microcalcifications, nor architectural distortion.  The overall appearance is
 stable since the prior exam.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: 51 year old woman status post repair of incarcerated hernia
 presents to rule out pneumothorax.

 COMPARISONS: None.

 Single frontal chest radiograph obtained in supine position shows no large
 pneumothorax.  However, the presence of a small pneumothorax cannot be
 excluded on this supine study.  An ETT is seen with tip at 2.5 cm above the
 carina.  An NGT has its tip below the diaphragm.  Areas of patchy subsegmental
 atelectasis are seen in bilateral lungs.  The presence of small pleural
 effusions cannot be rule out on this supine study.

FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL INFORMATION: Patient with history of pontine infarct now presenting
 with acute worsening and total plegia on the right for further evaluation.

 TECHNIQUE: T1 sagittal and axial, and FLAIR, T2 and susceptibility axial
 images of the brain were obtained before gadolinium. T1 axial images of the
 brain were also obtained following gadolinium. 3D time of flight MRA of the
 circle of [**Location (un) **] was acquired.

 FINDINGS

 BRAIN MRI:

 Comparison was made with the previous study of [**2109-1-5**].

 On the diffusion weighted images, there are two distinct infarct identified in
 the left pontine region with an infarct in the left cerebellar hemisphere.
 Since the previous study, the more anteriorly located pontine and left
 cerebellar infarcts are new.   No evidence of new infarct is seen in the
 supratentorial brain. There is no midline shift mass effect or hydrocephalus.
 Periventricular white matter changes are identified. No evidence of abnormal
 enhancement is seen following the administration of gadolinium.

 MRA OF THE HEAD:

 The 3D time of flight MRA of the head again demonstrates diffuse narrowing of
 the basilar artery with mid basilar stenosis and probable stenosis at the
 left vertebro-basilar junction. Right distal vertebral artery is not
 visualized. No significant interval change is seen on the MRA since the
 previous study.

IMPRESSION:
 Placement of a 14 French pigtail multisidehole catheter with the tip
 projecting over the gastric antrum. Failed initial placement of a MIC
 gastrostomy tube, and unsuccessful placement of 14 French gastrojejunostomy
 catheter due to significant difficulty getting beyond the proximal duodenum.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  42-year-old man, status post removal of right chest tube.  Assess
 for pneumothorax.

 COMPARISON:  Multiple prior studies with the latest on [**2190-2-11**] at 0932
 hours.

 SINGLE UPRIGHT PORTABLE CHEST RADIOGRAPH:  There is interval removal of the
 right-sided chest tube.  No pneumothorax is noted.  Mild bibasilar hazy
 opacities are unchanged and compatible with combination of bibasilar
 atelectasis and small pleural effusions.  The cardiomediastinal silhouette,
 hilar contours and pulmonary vasculature are normal.  A right IJ CVL
 terminates in the mid SVC, unchanged.  Median sternotomy wires are intact.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Left upper extremity edema status post right heart
 catheterization.

 MEDICATIONS: Moderate sedation was provided with divided doses of 0.5 mg IV

 continuous hemodynamic monitoring was performed.  Additionally, the patient

 PROCEDURE:  Prior to initiation of the procedure, written informed consent was
 obtained and a preprocedure timeout was performed.  Upon initiation of

 fluoroscopic spot image was performed demonstrating the nasogastric tube
 malpositioned within the retropharynx.  The nasogastric tube was removed and

 to access the stomach, for which an 0.035 J-wire was advanced.  Sequential
 fascial dilatation was performed followed by placement of a 12-French
 Wills-[**Doctor Last Name 7943**] tube.  The pigtail was formed within the stomach.  Contrast
 injection confirmed location.  The T-tacks were secured to the skin with 0
 silk suture.  A dressing was applied.  The patiet tolerated the procedure well
 and left the IR suite in good condition.

 tortuous iliac and femoral system.  Ultimately, a sheath exchange is performed
 over an exchange length 038 microwire for a 25 cm 6 French bright tip sheath.

 INDICATION:

 RADIOLOGISTS:
 Drs. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 629**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 884**], [**Name5 (PTitle) 737**] [**Doctor Last Name **] [**Doctor Last Name 325**], and [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2091**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 27**]. Drs.
 [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Name5 (PTitle) 325**] and [**Doctor Last Name 27**] were present throughout procedure.

 CONTRAST/MEDICATIONS:
 20 ml of Optiray 320 at 60%. 100 mcg of Fentanyl and 1 mg Versed were given
 intravenously in divided doses under continued hemodynamic monitoring for
 conscious sedation.

 PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE/FINDINGS:
 The procedure was described and informed consent obtained. The stomach was
 insufflated with air, and point of entry into the body of stomach was marked.
 Following local anesthetic infiltration, a 19 gauge spinal needle was inserted
 under fluoroscopic guidance until tenting of the stomach wall was noticed. The
 lumen of the stomach was then entered, and a flush of air was noted through
 the spinal needle. At this time, a 0.035 Bentson guidewire was placed through
 the needle into the lumen of the stomach, and the needle was removed. The
 tract was then dilated using 6, 8, 10, 12, and 14 French dilators under
 fluoroscopic guidance. A small amount of contrast material was injected during
 the course of dilatation which again demonstrated gastric location. The tract
 was continually dilated up to 18 French, and a 16 French MIC gastrostomy tube
 was advanced over a stiff guidewire. At this time, contrast was injected
 through the tube and demonstrated its tip to be still in the stomach. A
 significant amount of previously injected contrast material was noted in a
 large hiatal hernia projecting above the left hemidiaphragm. With the
 guidewire projecting over the body and fundus of the stomach, the securing
 balloon of the MIC gastrostomy tube was inflated with contrast material and
 normal saline, and was noticed to project outside the body of the stomach. The
 tube was deflated, the wire removed, and contrast material was then injected
 directly through the gastrostomy tube, which demonstrated a peritoneal
 location.

 The stomach was reinsufflated with air, and two T-fasteners were placed
 through the wall of the stomach and secured to the anterior abdominal wall. A
 19 gauge needle was then used to access the stomach in an adjacent separate
 puncture site over the anterior abdominal wall. An 0.035 wire was placed
 through the needle, the needle removed, the tract dilated to 7 French. A 7
 French sheath was then placed over the needle, and access into the gastric
 antrum was obtained. A 5 French multipurpose catheter was advanced over the
 guidewire, and the guidewire was exchanged for an angled glidewire. Following
 several technical manipulations, the guidewire was passed through the first
 portion of the duodenum and eventually beyond the ligament of Treitz. The
 multipurpose catheter was advanced over the guidewire, and the glidewire was
 exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff guidewire. The multipurpose catheter and
 7-French sheath were removed, and a 14 French dilator/peelaway sheath was then
 advanced over the Superstiff guidewire into the duodenum. The inner dilator
 was removed, and a 14 French [**Doctor Last Name 2583**] gastrojejunstomy catheter was placed
 through the peelaway sheath. With continued advancement of the catheter
 through the proximal duodenum, the guidewire in the ligament of Treitz
 retracted. This in part was due to the lack of flexibility in the
 gastroduodenal region, secondary to the presence of a large hiatal hernia. At
 this time, a T-fastener placed previously was noted to have dislodged during
 advancement of the catheter and peelaway sheath. At this time, four new T-
 fasteners were placed under fluoroscopic guidance under continued gas
 insufflation via the NG tube. Access was again gained to the body of the
 stomach, and a 14 French pigtail catheter was placed fluoroscopic guidance,
 such that the pigtail formed in the antrum of the stomach. The catheter was
 secured to the patient's skin using 0 Prolene suture material and Flexitrak
 dressing.

 COMPLICATIONS:
 Free air was noted under the hemidiaphragms during and following the
 procedure. The possibility of gastric versus duodenal perforation was a
 concern, and a CT scan of the abdomen was arranged for the following day.

IMPRESSION: Lateral fixation plate and interlocking screws of tibial plateau
 fracture with no hardware related complication.

 attending radiologist, present throughout the procedure.

 ANESTHESIA:  Local anesthesia was administered with 1% lidocaine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  A verbal consent was obtained after explaining the
 procedure and risks involved to the patient.  The right upper arm was prepped
 and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  A preprocedure huddle and timeout
 were performed as per [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.

 Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial vein was
 punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.  Hard
 copies of ultrasound images obtained before and immediately after establishing
 intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over the guide wire.
 There was difficulty in advancing the micropuncture wire through the right
 subclavian vein.  A venogram was performed using 20 cc of Optiray 60%.  The
 venogram demonstrates marked narrowing of the right subclavian vein with
 extensive venous collateralization.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 0.018
 guide wire was used to traverse the narrowed right subclavian vein.  A 4
 French PICC line measuring 40 cm was successfully positioned in the distal
 SVC.  The position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film
 of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guide wire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.  The patient
 tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate complications.

 Under sterile technique, the existing, non-functioning left-sided PICC line
 was removed.  A sterile dressing was again applied.

 FNA OF THE CERVICAL LYMPH NODES

 INDICATION:  73-year-old man with right-sided cervical lymphadenopathy
 concerning for malignancy.

 After risk, benefits, alternatives and procedure were explained to the
 patient, written informed consent was obtained.  A preprocedure timeout was
 performed using three patient identifiers.

 Initial ultrasound imaging showed three lymph nodes in the right side of neck,
 measuring up to 1.8 x 2 cm.  The middle of these was chosen for FNA due to
 size and relative distance from adjacent jugular and carotid vessels.

 The site in the right neck was marked, then prepped with alcohol.

 25-gauge needle was used to perform two passes of the FNA through the lymph
 nodes under direct ultrasound guidance (the first with suction and second
 without suction).  The material from the first pass was evaluated by on-site
 cytology team and was deemed adequate. The second sample was sent in cytolyte,
 as advised by cytology.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  No immediate post-procedure
 complications were noted.

 The attending radiologist, Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2916**] [**Name (STitle) 2917**] was present and supervised the
 whole procedure.

 MEDICAL HISTORY:  70-year-old man with thyroid and esophageal cancer needing
 chemotherapy.  The patient is known to have difficult venous access and IV
 team could only place a midline catheter as the wire could not be advanced
 centrally.  As the patient needs central access for chemotherapy, a request
 was placed for IR-guided exchange or placement of a new PICC line with tip
 positioned centrally.

 CLINICIANS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 9422**] [**Name (STitle) 90**] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the
 attending radiologist, reviewed the study.

 ANESHTESIA:  Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  A verbal consent was obtained after explaining the
 procedure and risks involved to the patient.  The left upper arm including the
 existing midline catheter was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.
 A preprocedure huddle and timeout were performed as per [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.

 Initial scout image of the left upper arm was obtained demonstrating a midline
 catheter with tip terminating just distal to the axilla.  Attempts to either
 aspirate blood or to flush through either port of the catheter were
 unsuccessful.  A 0.018 guidewire was placed through one of the ports, but the
 wire could not be advanced past the level of the axilla.  At this stage, a
 small amount of contrast was injected through one of the ports demonstrating
 the catheter to be extravascular.  Therefore, the catheter was removed.  A new
 access was obtained into a left brachial vein with a micropuncture set and
 ultrasound images were stored before and after gaining intravenous access.  A
 0.018 guidewire was placed through the micropuncture sheath, but again the
 wire could not be advanced past the level of axilla.  Therefore, a small
 amount of contrast was injected demonstrating patent but tortuous veins at the
 level of axilla.  A 0.035 Glidewire was placed through the micropuncture
 sheath and advanced easily past this level into SVC.  A 5 French Kumpe
 catheter was placed over the Glidewire and the wire exchanged for a 0.018 PICC
 line wire.  The Kumpe catheter was removed and a peel-away sheath was placed
 over the guidewire and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line measuring 55 cm in
 length was placed through the peel-away sheath with the tip positioned in the
 SVC under fluoroscopic guidance.  The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then
 removed.  A fluoroscopic spot chest film was obtained and stored digitally.
 The catheter was secured to skin with a Stat-Lock device and sterile dressings
 were applied.  Both ports of the catheter were easily aspirated and flushed.
 The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate
 complications.

 INDICATION:  Large right thyroid mass, FNA cytology demonstrating squamous

 METHODS: Approximately 1 hour after intravenous administration of F-18
 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), noncontrast CT images were obtained for attenuation
 correction and for fusion with emission PET images. [The noncontrast CT images
 are not used to diagnose disease independently of the PET images.]  A series of
 overlapping emission PET images was then obtained. The fasting blood glucose
 level, measured by glucometer before injection of FDG, was 96 mg/dL. The area
 imaged spanned the region from the  orbits to the thighs.

 Computed tomography (CT) images were co-registered and fused with emission PET
 images to assist with the anatomic localization of tracer uptake.  The
 determination of the site of tracer uptake seen on PET data can have important
 implications regarding the significance of that uptake.

 INTERPRETATION:

 HEAD/NECK: A large, lobulated mass with hetergeneous solid and cystic components
 arises from the right thyroid lobe and extends into the superior neck at the
 level of the mandible.  This lesion measures 7.3 cm TV x 5.2 cm AP x 8.2 cm CC,
 with SUVmax of 24.13.   There is severe mass effect on and compression of the
 trachea and esophagus.

 No FDG-avid intracranial lesions are seen in the imaged skull base.

 CHEST:  A long-segment region of circumferential wall thickening up to 1.5 cm is
 present in the mid-to-distal esophagus, with SUVmax of 35.12.  This abnormality
 spans a craniocaudal distance of approximately 9.4 cm, from the level of the
 carina to just above the gastroesophageal junction.

 An upper right paratracheal node measures 1.4 cm, with SUVmax of 17.45.  3-mm
 pulmonary nodule in the anterior right upper lobe is non-FDG-avid.  Thoracic
 aortic and three-vessel coronary artery calcifications are present.

 ABDOMEN/PELVIS:  No FDG-avid lesions are seen in the abdomen and pelvis.  Dense
 calcifications are present in the abdominal aorta and iliac arteries.

 MUSCULOSKELETAL:  No FDG-avid lesions are seen in the bones and soft tissues.

 Physiologic uptake is seen in the brain, myocardium, salivary glands, GI and  GU
 tracts, liver and spleen.

IMPRESSION:

 mid abdominal mesentery between loops of bowel.  This is consistent with
 mesenteric injury, and suspicious for small-bowel injury.

 represent a grade 1 laceration or a splenic cleft; however, if it represents a

 chronic.  Otherwise, no evidence for acute fracture or malalignment of the

 CLINICAL INDICATION: 52 year old man with cardiopath and previous pulmonary
 embolism, who presents with back and right leg pain in S1/S2 distribution.

 COMPARISON: Outside CT abdomen dated [**2195-7-15**].

 OPERATORS: [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 823**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 824**], Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 4396**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 291**]. The attending
 radiologist, Dr.[**Last Name (STitle) 291**], was supervising throughout the examination.

 TECHNIQUE:

 The risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were explained to the
 patient, and informed consent was obtained. The patient was transported to the
 neuro-angiography suite and placed on the table in prone position. The lower
 back was prepared and draped in the standard sterile fashion. Timeout was
 performed according to [**Hospital1 51**] protocol.

 The L4 vertebral level was localized with fluoroscopy. 1% lidocaine was
 utilized for local anesthesia. Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22-gauge spinal
 needle was inserted at L4 level at the midline. Spontaneous
 cerebrospinal fluid was obtained and immediately 15 cc of Isovue were
 administered intrathecally. The needle was subsequently removed. The patient
 was transported to the CT scanner for additional evaluation. There were no
 immediate complications.

 SEDATION: 100 mcg of Fentanyl and 2 mg of Versed were given in divided doses
 over total intraservice time of 25 minutes. Cardiorespiratory parameters were
 monitored continuously during the procedure.

Impression:
 1.  Moderately increased left ventricular cavity size with severe regional
 left ventricular systolic dysfunction.  The LVEF was severely depressed at
 29%.  There was MR evidence of a large, transmural anterior infarct.  The
 findings are consistent with a poor likelihood of functional recovery of these
 walls after mechanical revascularization.
 2. Normal right ventricular cavity size and function. The RVEF was normal at
 51%.
 3. Mild pulmonic and tricuspid regurgitation.
 4. Left atrial enlargement.

 who was present and supervised during whole procedure.

 PROCEDURE:  Placement of temporary hemodialysis catheter.

 ANESTHESIA:  Lidocaine was used for local anesthesia.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  After risks and benefits of the procedure as well as
 local anesthesia were explained, informed consent was obtained.  The patient
 was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table.
 The left side of the neck was prepared and draped in the usual sterile
 fashion.  The left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture
 needle under fluoroscopic guidance.  Hard copies of the ultrasound were
 stored.  A 0.018 wire was then placed through the needle into the SVC using
 flouroscopic guidance. A small incision was made over the needle and the
 needle was removed and replaced with a 4.5 French micropuncture sheath.  The
 wire and the inner 3 French sheath were removed and replaced with a 0.035
 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire with the tip of the [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire terminated in the IVC.  The 4.5
 French sheath was then removed over the wire and a 12 French dilator was
 placed over the wire to dilate the soft tissue tract into the left IJ.  The
 dilator was then removed. A 12 French triple lumen 20-cm temporary
 hemodialysis catheter with a VIP port was then placed over the wire into the
 left IJ with the tip eventually terminated in the right atrium.  All three
 ports of the catheter were aspirated and flushed easily.  The ports were
 capped.  The catheter was sutured to the skin and a sterile dressing was
 applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well, and there were no immediate
 complications.

 axial hematoma measuring roughly 8 mm in thickness and 3.5 cm in maximal

 anteriorly, which may represent acute, non-clotted blood.  This collection may

 There is moderate subarachnoid hemorrhage occupying the immediately subjacent

 No definite adjacent parenchymal contusion is seen, and there is no associated

 transtentorial herniation.  No significant extra-axial hematoma is identified
 at the corresponding left frontotemporal fracture site, though there is
 subarachnoid hemorrhage in the sulci in this region, and there may be a small
 parenchymal contusion, at the level of the left sylvian fissure.

 There is extensive left supra- and periorbital soft tissue edema and
 hemorrhage, which does not appear to violate the orbital cone, and the
 retrobulbar fat in both orbits, as well as the periorbita, is preserved,
 though there is a small amount of right intraorbital emphysema, subjacent to
 an oblique fracture through that orbital roof.  There is extensive acute
 hemorrhage within the nasal cavity and sphenoid sinus, bilaterally, with a
 blood-fluid level within the left maxillary antrum.  Review of bone window
 images demonstrates extensive comminution of the vertex skull fracture, with
 one dominant component continuing in an oblique coronal plane and traversing
 the lateral wall and medial aspect of the right orbit, exiting through the
 ipsilateral anterior clinoid process, as well as the sphenoid sinus and the
 basisphenoid portion of the clivus.  Note that though there is opacification
 of the right mastoid air cells and small fluid level within the ipsilateral
 middle ear cavity, no definite right temporal bone fracture is identified (on
 these 2.5 mm sections).

 The dominant fracture component traversing the left frontal extending into the
 temporal bone continues as a longitudinal fracture involving the mastoid
 portion of the left temporal bone which, again, is largely fluid-filled with
 fluid in the aditus ad antrum.  The relatively thick sections suggest some
 degree of dissociation as well as lateral displacement of the ossicular chain,
 related to the longitudinal fracture.  Additionally, there is a suggestion of
 an oblique-transverse component, extending medially, which transverses the
 bony vestibule, with the appearance of pneumolabyrinth. Though there is
 extensive pneumocephalus as well as apparent dural venous gas bubbles, likely
 related to the series of fractures, described above, there is no definite
 fracture line traversing the occipital condyles, jugular foramina or
 hypoglossal or carotid canals, on these sections.

 Also noted is extensive "smash" fracture involving the nose with extensively
 comminuted, overriding fractures of both nasal bones, likely involving the
 bony nasal septum and, probably, the maxillary spine of the nose.
